correction.p: OCR generated transcript has not been corrected.

normalization.p: Only minor normalization where needed, if any, is indicated via markup.

punctuation.p: All punctuation marks in the source text have been retained, and are represented by appropriate Unicode code points.
Punctuation may be marked up with pc elements for clarification, but not exclusively.

quotation.p: All quotation marks have been retained, and are represented by appropriate Unicode code points.

hyphenation.p: Hyphenated words that appear at the end of a line have been retained. The hyphen, if present, is represented by the Unicode code point, and marked up with a pc element. The break="no" attribute on the lb element indicates that a single word is split across the lines.

interpretation.p: Dates, places, and names may be marked up, where useful.

body.ab:
Dozens of
Cousins
Printed 2005
[A transcription of this page is not available.]
Forward
The following was taken from a prior version of Dozens of Cousins written by Shirley
Frost Regan in September, 1974.
"How many times have you heard: "I know we're cousins, but how come?" Well, back in
1957 I wondered the same thing, so I started investigating the family history. Several years
before, Florence McLaughlin Frost had compiled the information but there was only one copy,
and some historian along the way had misplaced it. I started with three of our ancestors on
Page 1 who were most helpful: Kathryn McLaughlin Hendrick, Catherine Hendrick
McLaughlin and Charles Touhey. From them I received the basic outline. The rest was
obtained from many living McLaughlin's — and dates on tombstones!
I set up three duplicate notebooks, arranged so that pages can be inserted for many
generations to come. Then, we decided to have a printer make up a booklet. This was
distributed in 1958. Since then, many moons and one disastrous flood have come and gone.
So have most of the booklets! Since there was a great deal of data to be added, it was
suggested that a new history be written. Now, after two years of procrastination on my
part—and several years of inflation on the part of the economy— a less expensive revision is
herein presented. These are Xerox copies and will be easy to duplicate at any time.
That's the story, but, as usual, I'd like to add a few personal comments. First of all, the
research was rewarding. I now knew from what branch of the family tree I had fallen. And I
also knew how come the Touhey's, Keenan's et al, were my cousins.
Secondly, it brings back a smile from my memory bank. I was being "courted" by James
H. Regan at the time and I'm sure he felt that poking around cemeteries — looking for my
ancestors— was an exciting Saturday afternoon date!
Above all, though, I wish that this younger generation— and those to come— had been as
fortunate as I was in knowing almost all the people in this booklet. The names and dates are
here, but the warmth of their personalities cannot be put on paper. The McLaughlin's were
industrious, witty, honest, wonderful descendants of Irish immigrants of the 19* century. They
were — and are — an important part of our American heritage. I'm proud to be one of 'em!"
Shirley Frost Regan
Fast forward to 2005 and you now have a computer generated booklet created from a
program that Shirley would have loved. John Morovich was instrumental in getting the
information into the Family Tree Maker format back in 1997, and it has been my job to up
date, print and distribute the end result. I, too, can attribute procrastination as the reason it has
taken so long. So glad it runs in the family!!
Thank you to everyone who has taken the time to contribute their time, knowledge, and
family information. If I named everyone instrumental in getting this project done I'd probably
forget someone and then be in big trouble.
If you have additions, corrections or deletions that need to be made, you can drop me a
note via e-mail at www.CarollOl 1 l@.iuno.com.
[A transcription of this page is not available.]
